Dopamine: Increased dopaminergic transmission, particularly in the mesocorticolimbic pathway, may contribute to the onset and exacerbation of hallucinations ; Both dopamine deficiency and excess dopamine from medication may alter dopamine-related synaptic plasticity
Serotonin: Elevated levels of 5-HT2A serotonergic receptor binding in the ventral visual pathway, medial orbitofrontal cortex, and insula have been linked to visual hallucinations; Levodopa can act as a partial agonist at 5-HT2A receptors, which may contribute to the development of Parkinson’s disease psychosis (PDP)
Acetylcholine: Cholinergic innervation deficits, caused by the degeneration of basal forebrain cholinergic nuclei, may affect the processing of complex visual stimuli, contributing to the development of visual hallucinations
Cannabinoid receptor: Alterations in the cannabinoid system have been observed, with decreased CB1 receptor availability in the substantia nigra but increased density in other areas
Auditory brain regions: Auditory hallucinations are thought to involve the primary auditory cortex (superior temporal gyrus), secondary auditory association areas, and language processing areas such as Wernicke’s and Broca’s areas; Reduced grey matter volume in the superior temporal gyrus is a common finding in patients experiencing auditory hallucinations; Increased activity in language areas and the primary auditory cortex has been observed during active hallucination; Altered connectivity among temporal, prefrontal, and anterior cingulate regions has been reported
Visual brain regions: Visual hallucinations are associated with alterations in both the dorsal and ventral visual pathways; The dorsal stream is involved in processing spatial location and motion; Hypometabolism and reduced activation in regions such as the superior parietal lobe, precuneus, and middle temporal gyrus may contribute to visual hallucinations; The ventral stream is involved in object recognition; Hypometabolism in the fusiform gyrus, inferior temporal gyrus, and parahippocampal gyrus may play a role in visual hallucinations; Atrophy in the cuneus, middle occipital gyrus, and lingual gyrus are commonly reported
Frontal cortex: Altered activity and atrophy in the frontal cortex, including the prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate cortex, have been associated with hallucinations; These regions are involved in attention, self-monitoring, and the distinction between internally and externally generated stimuli
Limbic system: The limbic system, including the hippocampus, amygdala, and cingulate gyrus, plays a role in the emotional and memory aspects of hallucinations
Thalamus: The thalamus is a crucial hub for information flow between distributed cortical networks; Thalamic hypometabolism, atrophy, and disconnection from posterior brain areas are linked to aberrant disinhibition of the default mode network (DMN), which may contribute to hallucinations
Cholinergic structures: Degeneration of cholinergic structures, such as the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) and substantia innominata (SI), a part of the basal forebrain, have been associated with hallucinations
Default Mode Network (DMN): The DMN is involved in internal mentation tasks, such as introspection and mental imagery; Aberrant coupling of the DMN with visual networks is a common finding in individuals experiencing hallucinations, suggesting that internally generated mental imagery may intrude on visual perception
Dorsal Attention Network (DAN): The DAN is responsible for goal-directed and sustained attention; Dysfunction in the DAN, leading to a failure in recruiting this network during ambiguous visual input, may result in the incorporation of perceptual errors into the visual processing stream
Ventral Attention Network (VAN): Enhanced signaling through the VAN, especially through overactivation of the amygdala, can increase susceptibility to interference by irrelevant stimuli
Frontotemporal connectivity: Reduced functional connectivity between the frontal and temporal lobes has been linked to the misattribution of internally generated speech or sensory stimuli as external
Thalamocortical circuits: Disconnection between the thalamus and posterior brain areas is thought to lead to aberrant disinhibition of the DMN
Misattribution of internal stimuli: A prominent theory suggests that hallucinations arise from a misattribution of internally generated speech or sensory stimuli as coming from an external source
Self-monitoring deficits: Hallucinating individuals may have deficits in self-monitoring, which is the ability to distinguish between self-generated and externally generated stimuli; This may result from a lack of connectivity between brain regions that initiate an action and those that perceive its sensory consequences
Reality monitoring: Hallucinations may be linked to difficulties in reality monitoring, where the individual has trouble distinguishing between internally generated information and external reality
Attentional control: Reduced attentional control over interference may play a role in the emergence of minor hallucinations
Bottom-up and top-down processing: Hallucinations may arise from a failure of bottom-up processing of sensory information, leading to an over-reliance on top-down processing, which results in misinterpretations of the environment

Dopamine: There is a progressive dopaminergic neuronal death in the nigrostriatal pathway in PD; Dysfunction occurs in the presynaptic terminals of the mesolimbic dopaminergic system; There is decreased dopamine transporter (DAT) binding and reduced dopaminergic metabolism; An imbalance of D3 versus D2 receptors is also observed
Serotonin: There are decreased levels of serotonin (5-HT) in the striatum and other areas ; There is increased serotonin transporter (SERT) binding in some areas, possibly reflecting greater serotonin clearance, and decreased SERT in the limbic system; There are also lower levels of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA), a 5-HT metabolite, in PD patients with depression; 5-HT reuptake sites are abnormally diminished in PD patients with or without depression, and serotonergic neurons in the raphe nucleus degrade more severely in PD patients with depression
Acetylcholine: Cortical cholinergic loss is related to depression in PD; There are decreases in binding to α4β2-nicotinic receptors
Thalamus: Decreased dopamine levels in the thalamus can affect motor function and emotion; Noradrenergic dysfunction in the thalamus has been related to PD depression and anxiety; The limbic thalamus is also part of the areas that show altered connectivity in DPD
Norepinephrine: Noradrenergic deficits are seen in prodromal and idiopathic PD; There is reduced norepinephrine transporter binding in the locus coeruleus (LC), which is the principal noradrenergic nucleus in the CNS; The accumulation of α-synuclein in LC results in LC neuronal loss and degeneration, which may result in reduced levels of norepinephrine (NE) in several brain areas
Inflammation: Increased levels of pro-inflammatory molecules are implicated; There are elevated levels of soluble interleukin-2 receptor (sIL-2R), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNFα), and C-reactive protein (CRP); Inflammation may reduce 5-HT levels via an indoleamine-2, 3-dioxygenase (IDO) mediated reduction in tryptophan
Trophic Factors: There are disruptions in neurotrophic factors, particularly decreased levels of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF); BDNF is involved in neuronal plasticity, and its decrease may contribute to depression
Synucleinopathy: There is increased synucleinopathy in the substantia nigra, ventral tegmental area, and nucleus accumbens in patients with Lewy body disorders and depression; Alpha-synuclein becomes misfolded and clumps together and is cytotoxic
Gut Microbiota: A leaky gut and related inflammatory responses have been linked to depression in PD; Alterations in gut microbiota may contribute to the severity of depressive symptoms
Basal Ganglia: The basal ganglia, including the striatum, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus, are key regions affected in PD; The mesolimbic dopamine system, which connects the ventral tegmental area (VTA) to the nucleus accumbens (NAc), is disrupted; Dopamine neuron degeneration in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNpc) affects motor and emotional processing; The ventral striatum is involved in reward and emotions, and changes there may contribute to depressive symptoms; Lower dopamine levels in the caudate nucleus of the striatum are observed in PD patients with depression compared to those without
Amygdala: Hypermetabolism in the amygdala has been noted; Reduced connectivity between the amygdala and frontoparietal regions is also observed in depressed patients; The amygdala is also impacted by increased SERT binding and lower levels of 5HT1A receptors
Hippocampus: Reduced hippocampal volume is related to depression; There is also lower binding of 5HT1A receptors in the hippocampus
Prefrontal Cortex: Dysfunction in the prefrontal cortex is linked to depression in PD
Orbitofrontal Cortex: Lower grey matter density and hypometabolism are seen in this region; A neural circuit between the VTA and orbitofrontal cortex may play a role in developing depression
Anterior Cingulate Cortex (ACC): Hypometabolism and lower grey matter density are observed; Decreased SERT in the subgenual ACC is related to depression; There is also decreased binding to nicotinic receptors in the ACC
Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex: This region is targeted by TMS to alleviate depression
Locus Coeruleus (LC): As mentioned above, the principal noradrenergic nucleus in the CNS, undergoes degeneration and has reduced NE, and its function is related to depression in PD
Raphe Nuclei: These nuclei are key for serotonergic transmission. Increased SERT binding and decreased levels of 5-HT are observed in this region
Limbic Circuits: There is widespread dysfunction of the limbic network, including altered connectivity
Corticostriatal Circuits: These circuits are affected by structural and functional changes
Striatal-Thalmic-Prefrontal Circuits: Dysfunction in these circuits is implicated in PD depression
Frontemporal Regions: Altered functional connectivity between the striatum, thalamus, and these regions is observed in depressed patients; Functional connectivity in the posterior cingulate cortex is increased in patients with PD depression; Reduced connectivity in cortical-subcortical limbic circuities and increased connectivity between specific limbic areas (amygdala, limbic thalamus, temporal cortex) have been identified in DPD
Gut-Brain Axis: The microbiota-gut-brain signaling is implicated in non-motor symptoms, including depressive disorders in PD
Emotional Regulation: The disruption of limbic circuits and neurotransmitter systems interferes with emotional regulation, resulting in depressive symptoms
Reward System: The mesolimbic dopamine reward circuit is disrupted in early stages of PD ; Dopamine deficiency generates dysregulations in the dopamine-mediated reward system, leading to disorders like anhedonia
Cognitive Impairment: Depression and cognitive impairment share many common risk factors; Depression can predict a decline in cognitive performance, and cognitive decline is also related to depression; Poorer multi-domain cognitive performance predicts increased incidence of depression and anxiety in early PD
Stress Response: The mesocortical and noradrenergic stress-response systems are dysfunctional ; Dysregulation of the HPA axis and increased cortisol levels can exacerbate depression and motor functions in PD; Chronic stress may increase the vulnerability of dopaminergic neurons to degeneration

Basal Ganglia: The basal ganglia has connections to brain areas that regulate emotion, anxiety, and fear, but its exact role in mediating these responses is not clear
Amygdala: The amygdala and associated limbic structures play a crucial role in the expression of emotions like fear and anxiety; Perturbation of dopaminergic input to the amygdala is implicated in abnormal emotional expression in PD patients; Studies have shown increased amygdala metabolism in depressed PD patients
Hippocampus: This area receives noradrenergic input from the locus coeruleus and is involved in integrating responses to anxiety
Prefrontal Cortex: Dopamine depletion in the prefrontal cortex has been linked to anxiety-like behavior; Studies have shown increased neural activity in prefrontal regions in depressed PD patients; There is also evidence of decreased functional connectivity between the prefrontal and limbic structures in depressed PD patients
Locus Coeruleus (LC): This region is involved in noradrenergic transmission, and cell loss in this area can contribute to anxiety in PD; Lower dopamine/noradrenaline transporter binding in this area is associated with increased anxiety
Dopaminergic Neuron Loss: The cardinal motor symptoms of PD result from the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNpc); This dopamine depletion is also linked to anxiety; Anxiety symptoms may be more sensitive to dopamine depletion than motor symptoms
Serotonergic Cell Loss: Serotonergic neurons in the raphe nuclei, which provide input to corticolimbic structures involved in anxiety, are lost prior to nigrostriatal dopaminergic degeneration; Abnormalities in the action of serotonin (5-HT) are linked to anxiety
Noradrenergic Dysfunction: Noradrenergic projections from the locus coeruleus, which innervate areas involved in integrating anxiety responses, are impacted by cell loss in PD ; Changes in the expression of noradrenaline (NA) receptors and transporters may lead to or worsen anxiety
GABA and Glutamate: Abnormalities in the gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glutamate neurotransmitter systems have been shown in patients with PD and may be involved in the development of anxiety; Drugs that modulate these systems have shown potential to treat anxiety
Corticolimbic Circuits: Serotonergic neurons project to these circuits involved in anxious states, suggesting that abnormalities in serotonin action in these networks contribute to anxiety
Connections between emotional and motor: The connections between brain areas controlling emotions and those controlling posture may contribute to the manifestation of anxiety in PD, and postural control may be affected by anxiety
Social Anxiety: Patients with PD may experience social anxiety due to fear of negative public evaluation; Social phobia is associated with suppression of dopaminergic transmission
"Reactive" Anxiety: Anxiety may be a reaction to the psychosocial stress of having a chronic disease like PD and the associated disability
Anxious Personality: Some studies suggest that individuals with an anxious personality may have an increased risk of developing PD, implying shared biological mechanisms between anxiety and PD
Impulse Control Disorders (ICDs): ICDs, which are characterized by a failure to resist an impulse, are a group of anxiogenic conditions that have received special attention in PD; These disorders involve the ventral striatum and may be influenced by dopamine agonists, particularly those with relative selectivity for D3 receptors

Dopamine: Apathy is frequently associated with a dysfunction in the dopaminergic system, which plays a crucial role in motivation and reward-based behaviors; Reduced dopamine release and transmission in the mesocorticolimbic pathway is linked to motivational apathy, which is a type of apathy characterized by a lack of emotional resonance; This pathway includes the ventral tegmental area (VTA), nucleus accumbens (NAc), and prefrontal cortex ; Dopamine modulates reward-based behaviors through striatal projections ; Approach behaviors are mediated by the direct pathway with D1 receptors (D1Rs), while avoidance behaviors use the indirect pathway with D2 receptors (D2Rs) ; Partial dopamine denervation in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) impairs motivational preparatory processes, resembling some forms of apathy ; Apathy can result from a severe dopamine depletion state in the mesocorticolimbic system
Serotonin: Serotonergic denervation within the mesocorticolimbic pathway also contributes to motivational apathy; Serotonergic circuits may compensate for DA denervation, and combined DA and serotonergic denervation may underlie motivational apathy
Thalamus: The medial thalamus is implicated in apathy, with lesions in this area leading to reduced spontaneous activity
Prefrontal Cortex: The PFC plays a crucial role in goal-directed behavior, executive functions, and emotional processing
Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex: The DLPFC is involved in executive functions, such as planning and organizing; Dysfunction here can lead to cognitive apathy, which is related to deficits in planning and cognitive control
Cholinergic and Noradrenergic Systems: Cholinergic and noradrenergic systems are also implicated, especially in cognitive apathy; Cholinergic denervation can impair attention and executive functions, while noradrenergic deficits contribute to apathy through reduced precision of expected outcomes
Medial Frontal Cortex (ACC and Orbitofro: These areas are consistently linked to apathy across various pathologies; Dysfunction in the ACC and OFC contributes to deficits in motivation, emotional processing and decision-making; Specifically, the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) plays a role in initiating and sustaining actions; The orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) is involved in reward processing and emotional responses; The medial orbitofrontal cortex (mOFC) is linked to hedonic impact or "liking" ; Hypometabolism in the orbitofrontal cortex and anterior cingulate is associated with apathy
Striatum: The striatum, which includes the caudate and putamen, is a critical part of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control, reward processing, and motivation; The ventral striatum (VS) is particularly important in reward anticipation and processing, and it is part of the mesolimbic pathway; Reduced activity or connectivity in the VS is linked to apathy; The caudate nucleus is involved in executive functions
Other regions: Other regions that are implicated in apathy include the posterior cingulate cortex, putamen, inferior temporal cortex, and insula
Cortico-basal ganglia circuits: These involve the prefrontal cortex, basal ganglia (including the striatum, globus pallidus, and substantia nigra), and thalamus; Three main corticostriatal circuits are identified: sensorimotor, associative, and limbic; These circuits are involved in motor control, cognitive processes, and emotional regulation, respectively; Disruptions within these networks, especially involving connections between the prefrontal cortex and limbic system, can lead to apathy
Mesocorticolimbic Pathway: Dysfunction in this pathway is strongly linked to motivational apathy; It involves the VTA, NAc, and prefrontal cortex
Reward Circuitry: Apathy is associated with disruption in the reward circuitry, which involves the VTA, nucleus accumbens, orbitofrontal cortex, and other regions; Apathy may result from a failure to generate options for behavior, impaired selection between options, and reduced ability to learn from outcomes
White Matter Tracts: White matter tracts, such as the anterior cingulum, play a role in the development of apathy; Damage to these tracts disrupts communication between brain regions
Motivation and Goal-Directed Behavior: Sensitivity to stimuli - deficits in responding to internal or external stimuli; Reward processing - Diminished ability to attach motivational value to stimuli, and reduced anticipation or experience of pleasure; Decision making - impaired ability to select actions based on their potential costs and benefits; Initiation and execution of actions - difficulty in starting and carrying out actions; Effort-based decision making (EBDM) - Apathy may result from a reduced sensitivity to rewards or an increased sensitivity to effort costs. This can disrupt the initiation, vigor, and persistence of actions
Executive Functions: Deficits in executive functions, such as planning, organizing, and sustaining attention, contribute to cognitive apathy
Self-activation: Apathy can result from the inability to activate oneself, or to initiate mental processing without external stimulation
Emotional Processing: Apathy involves emotional blunting or indifference, which is a key differentiator from depression

Dopamine: Repeated exposure to dopaminergic drugs can cause neuroadaptations in the nucleus accumbens, resulting in long-lasting changes in dopaminergic and GABAergic neurotransmission; This leads to a state of hypersensitivity to the rewarding effects of these drugs ; The dopamine system becomes hyper-responsive, attributing increased "incentive salience" to the dopaminergic drugs; This means that the drugs themselves are attributed with attractive properties, leading to an intense "wanting" or craving, separate from the "liking" or pleasure derived from the drugs
Orbitofrontal Cortex: The orbitofrontal cortex plays a critical role in impulse control, risk-taking, and the ability to delay immediate gratification for future rewards; Dysfunction in this area can contribute to the loss of control over drug-taking and other repetitive and impulsive behaviors
Reward Circuitry: DDS involves dysfunction within the neural system that is involved in reward signaling; Dopamine replacement therapy, while aiming to restore normal dopamine levels in motor pathways, can abnormally stimulate the mesocorticolimbic system, leading to addictive disorders; This network is also implicated in the development of impulse control disorders
Glutamate: Neuroadaptations in cortico-striatal glutamatergic projections, which occur with repeated exposure to salient stimuli, enhance motivation for reward-seeking and craving
Ventral Striatum: Studies have shown that PD patients with DDS have increased levodopa-induced dopamine release in the ventral striatum compared to matched patients without DDS; This increased dopamine release correlates with self-reported compulsive drug "wanting" but not "liking"
Fronto-striatal Disconnection: A disconnection in the fronto-striatal pathway has been observed in PD patients with pathological gambling, which is often associated with DDS
Fronto-Striatal Network: This network, which includes the orbitofrontal cortex, is crucial for goal-directed behavior and impulse control; Alterations in the connectivity within this network are thought to contribute to the development of DDS
Impaired Executive Function: While not a primary feature of DDS, impaired executive functions, particularly in decision-making and learning from negative feedback, may contribute to the development of compulsive behaviors; Some studies suggest that difficulties with selective and sustained attention may be present in DDS patients, possibly due to higher medication intake
Loss of Inhibitory Control: A relative imbalance between enhanced appetitive drive and reduced top-down inhibitory control from prefrontal cortical areas has been hypothesized to underlie the pathophysiology of ICDs in PD
Negative Reinforcement: Patients with DDS often report that their drug use is driven by a need to avoid unpleasant OFF symptoms; The negative experiences associated with end-of-dose wearing off and the presence of a chronic depressive state may enhance the incentive value of dopaminergic drugs

Dopamine: Dopamine plays a significant role in the regulation of sleep and circadian homeostasis; In PD, the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons, particularly in the substantia nigra, disrupts the normal sleep-wake cycle; The loss of dopamine affects the balance of neurotransmitters that regulate sleep, such as GABA, acetylcholine, and glutamate
Amygdala: This region of the brain is linked to the emotional content of dreams and may be implicated in REM sleep behavior disorder
Hypothalamus: The suprachiasmatic nuclei (SCN) in the hypothalamus is the location of the endogenous oscillator, or "master clock" of the circadian system
GABA: GABAergic neurons in the forebrain preoptic nucleus play a role in the transition from wakefulness to non-REM sleep; An imbalance between GABA and glutamate, especially in brainstem-subcortical circuits, can contribute to REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD)
Melatonin: The circadian rhythm of melatonin can be reduced or phase-advanced in PD patients, which can lead to poor sleep
Orexin/Hypocretin: Although primarily related to daytime sleepiness, the loss of hypocretin neurons in the hypothalamus may also impact overall sleep regulation
Alpha-synuclein: Accumulation of alpha-synuclein is a key feature of PD and may play a role in sleep disturbances, particularly RBD; It may also cause endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and impact cellular "quality control machinery" leading to sleep problems
Substantia Nigra: Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in this area is a hallmark of PD and disrupts the sleep-wake cycle
Brainstem: The brainstem contains several nuclei, such as the locus coeruleus, dorsal raphe nucleus, and pedunculopontine nucleus, which are involved in the regulation of sleep and wakefulness; Degeneration in these regions can lead to sleep disturbances ; The sublaterodorsal tegmental nucleus (SLD) in the pons is involved in the generation of REM sleep
Forebrain: The preoptic area (POA), particularly the ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO) and the median preoptic nucleus (MnPn), is important for promoting non-REM sleep; The basal forebrain is also involved in the sleep-wake cycle
Ascending Reticular Activating System (A: This network includes various neurotransmitter systems that control wakefulness and arousal through projections to the thalamus and neocortex, and is affected in PD
Circadian System: The circadian system comprises the endogenous oscillator in the SCN, entrainment agents (zeitgebers), and pathways that couple the internal clock to physiological and behavioral rhythms; Dopamine plays a role in this system; Dysfunction of this system is implicated in poor sleep quality
REM sleep circuitry: The glutamatergic neurons in the sublaterodorsal tegmental nucleus and the subceruleus and magnocellularis nuclei in the brainstem are part of the network that controls REM sleep; Breakdown of this network is implicated in RBD
Sleep architecture: PD affects both sleep macrostructure (sleep fragmentation, increased superficial sleep) and microstructure (disturbed sleep spindles and K-complexes); Sleep efficiency is reduced in PD
Motor control: Nocturnal akinesia or hypokinesia can disrupt sleep and mimic symptoms of restless leg syndrome; Impaired turning ability in bed is also associated with sleep disturbances
REM sleep without atonia (RWA): The loss of muscle atonia during REM sleep is a key feature of RBD, which is common in PD; The network that inhibits muscle movement during REM sleep breaks down in RBD, which can result in dream enactment
Cognitive Dysfunction: Cognitive impairment can lead to difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep
Depression and anxiety: Depression is common in PD and may contribute to sleep disturbances, particularly insomnia

Dopamine: Dopaminergic areas are affected by neurodegeneration in PD; Dopaminergic medications can also contribute to somnolence
Serotonin: The serotonergic dorsal raphe nucleus is part of the ascending arousal system
Norepinephrine: The noradrenergic locus coeruleus and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus nerve are involved in arousal
Hypothalamus: The lateral hypothalamus, which contains hypocretin cells, is involved in maintaining wakefulness; Hypocretin cell loss in PD can lead to sleep disorders
GABA: A ligand of the benzodiazepine allosteric site of GABAA receptors, eszopiclone, has been studied for insomnia in PD
Brainstem: Neurodegeneration within the ascending arousal systems in the brainstem affects neurotransmission across several neuronal nuclei; The brainstem is crucial for regulating sleep and wakefulness, with specific nuclei, such as the locus coeruleus, dorsal raphe nucleus, and tuberomammillary nucleus, being affected by PD
Cholinergic neurons: Promote REM sleep in the laterodorsal tegmental and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei
Histamine: The histaminergic tuberomammillary nucleus is also involved in wakefulness
Hypocretin (Orexin): Loss of hypocretin cells in the hypothalamus may contribute to EDS in PD; Reduced hypocretin levels have been found in the prefrontal cortex and lateral ventricle
Basal Forebrain: This area, part of the ascending arousal system, is also impacted in PD
Caudate: Dopamine denervation in the caudate has been linked to EDS
Ascending Arousal System: This network, involving the brainstem and other regions, is critical for maintaining wakefulness; Neurodegeneration in PD disrupts this system, leading to sleep disorders
Circadian Rhythm Regulation: Disruptions in the sleep-wake cycle can occur in PD due to the neurodegenerative process; Specifically, there is a loss of rhythmicity in circadian genes
Cognitive Decline: EDS is associated with an increased risk of cognitive decline; Sleepiness itself can worsen cognitive function
Awareness of Sleepiness: Some PD patients may not be aware of their sleepiness; Dopamine agonists may also reduce awareness of falling asleep
Impact on Daily Functioning: EDS significantly impairs daytime functioning and impacts the quality of life, and can lead to motor vehicle crashes
